content:
Input
* Line 2: I added "(in percent)" to the description.

Constraints
* I removed the first constraint "All the probabilities are written in percent" as it's more appropriate to appear as part of the input description (see above).

* I changed the second constraint from "0 < N < 100" to "1 ≤ N ≤ 10" to better reflect the actual cases.

Cases
* "All 100" (test): I modified the case so that N became 7 (originally 4).

* "All the same" (test): I modified the case so that N became 6 (originally 4).

I just played the clash and I get fooled by the fact that all the public test cases have a value n such that 100/n is an integer, but two validators have actually a value n equal to 7 or 8. As in all clashes, validators and public test cases should be similar. I modified the validators to avoid this misleading for future players.
I've updated the third validator, as it was tough for languages that treat floating numbers explicitly (plus there was no public test case verifying the same).

I was going to add more test cases but apparently the given solution fails with input "33 33 33" because it does some silly rounding. Someone with more motivation than me should probably rework this clash a little bit, the statement is still confusing and the test cases are much more constained than the statement would lead you to believe.
OK, I like it. Statement is a little complicated, but the example is good so it is doable in given time.

The 25 50 25 50 example makes it look like you're supposed to output "50" because that's the number equal to its Q. If you change the description to use the (10 25 50 50) example it'll be easier to understand.
Other than that, great puzzle.
There is only one line, not two lines.
It was a little ambiguous indeed, it's fixed now, thank you

I've restored the validators to their original inputs and adjusted the corresponding test cases instead. There's no reason to restrict the values of n to those where 100 / n is an integer; keeping the original validators ensures more robust checking.
